icons.message: Extend Tire Life with Proper Alignment

icons.name: Brakes
icons.message: Get peace of mind on the road and check your brakes.

icons.message: Get peace of mind on the road and check your brakes.

icons.name: Catalytic Converters
icons.message: Get peace of mind on the road and check your brakes.

tires.name: Tire Balancing
tires.factone: Noticeable vibrations while driving could mean your tires are out of balance. Don't ignore this sign â€“ get them checked!
tires.facttwo: To balance a tire, a technician adds small weights to the wheel, offsetting any unevenness.
tires.factthree: Regular balancing extends tire life, which saves you money in the long run by preventing premature wear and tear.

tires.name: Tire Repair
tires.factone: A tire with a puncture might be repairable, but it depends on the angle of the hole and how much tread is left. Steeper angles or low tread can make repairs unsafe.
tires.facttwo: Fixing tires is dependant on the angle and the tread depth.
tires.factthree: The penny test, cracks or bulges, and sidewall punctures are all signs that it's time to replace your tires.

tires.name: Tire Pressure
tires.factone: Tire pressure changes with temperature, dropping roughly 1 PSI for every 10 degrees Fahrenheit decrease. This can affect your car's handling and fuel economy.
tires.facttwo: Your car has a specific recommended tire pressure, which is usually listed on a sticker on the driver's side doorjamb. Be sure to check it regularly
tires.factthree: It is recommended to have a spare tire in case of a flat.

tires.name: Nitrogen
tires.factone: Nitrogen in tires helps maintain more stable pressure by reducing pressure loss and minimizing fluctuations due to temperature changes.
tires.facttwo: While nitrogen can help extend tire life, it's important to remember that regular tire maintenance, like rotations and alignments, is still crucial.
tires.factthree: Consider using nitrogen in your tires for improved fuel efficiency and longer tire life, especially if you frequently drive long distances or in varying temperatures.

tires.name: Wheel alignment
tires.factone: Proper wheel alignment ensures your car tracks straight and your tires wear evenly, preventing premature wear and tear.
tires.facttwo: If your car pulls to one side or your tires show uneven wear patterns, it's a sign you might need an alignment.
tires.factthree: Regular alignments can save you money in the long run by extending the life of your tires and improving fuel efficiency.

tires.name: Tire Rotation
tires.factone: Rotating your tires regularly helps ensure they wear evenly, extending their lifespan and improving your car's handling.
tires.facttwo: Most manufacturers recommend rotating your tires every 5,000 to 8,000 miles, but check your owner's manual for specific recommendations.
tires.factthree: Don't forget to check your tire pressure and inspect your tires for any signs of damage when you rotate them.

suspension.name: Suspension
suspension.factone: Your car's suspension system ensures a smooth ride and helps maintain control by absorbing bumps and keeping your tires in contact with the road.
suspension.facttwo: Worn suspension components can affect your car's handling, braking, and overall safety. If you notice excessive bouncing, swaying, or unusual noises, it's time for an inspection.
suspension.factthree: Regularly inspect your suspension system for signs of wear and tear, such as leaking shocks or worn-out bushings, to ensure a safe and comfortable ride.

batteries.name: Battery Replacement
batteries.factone: Car batteries typically last 3 to 5 years, but extreme temperatures and driving habits can affect their lifespan.
batteries.facttwo: If your car struggles to start or your lights seem dim, it might be time for a battery check and possible replacement.
batteries.factthree: Regular battery maintenance, such as cleaning terminals and checking the electrolyte level, can help prolong its life.

batteries.name: Alternator Check
batteries.factone: The alternator is responsible for charging your car's battery and powering the electrical system while the engine is running.
batteries.facttwo: A failing alternator can lead to a dead battery and other electrical problems. If your battery warning light is on, have your alternator checked.
batteries.factthree: Regularly inspecting your alternator belt for wear and tear can help prevent unexpected breakdowns.

batteries.name: Starter Testing
batteries.factone: The starter motor is responsible for cranking your engine to get it started.
batteries.facttwo: If you hear a clicking sound when you turn the key, or your engine doesn't crank at all, your starter might be failing.
batteries.factthree: Regularly checking your battery connections and ensuring your engine is properly tuned can help prevent starter problems.

brakes.name: Brake Check
brakes.factone: Your brakes are one of the most important safety features on your car. Regular inspections are crucial for safe driving.
brakes.facttwo: If you hear squealing or grinding noises, feel vibrations when braking, or notice your car pulling to one side, have your brakes checked immediately.
brakes.factthree: Brake fluid flushes and regular pad/rotor replacements are essential for maintaining optimal braking performance.

brakes.name: Rotor Replacement
brakes.factone: Brake rotors are metal discs that the brake pads clamp down on to stop your car.
brakes.facttwo: Worn or warped rotors can reduce braking efficiency and cause vibrations. If your rotors are damaged, it's important to replace them promptly.
brakes.factthree: High-quality rotors and proper installation can ensure smooth and reliable braking performance.

brakes.name: Rotor Resurfacing
brakes.factone: In some cases, slightly worn or warped rotors can be resurfaced instead of replaced, saving you money.
brakes.facttwo: Resurfacing involves removing a thin layer of metal from the rotor to create a smooth surface for the brake pads.
brakes.factthree: However, rotors can only be resurfaced a limited number of times before they need to be replaced.

mufflers.name: Muffler Installation
mufflers.factone: A properly functioning muffler reduces engine noise and directs exhaust fumes away from the vehicle.
mufflers.facttwo: If your muffler is damaged or rusted, it can lead to excessive noise and potentially harmful exhaust leaks.
mufflers.factthree: Choose a high-quality muffler and have it installed by a professional for optimal performance and longevity.

mufflers.name: Exhaust Manifolds
mufflers.factone: The exhaust manifold collects exhaust gases from the engine cylinders and directs them to the exhaust pipe.
mufflers.facttwo: Cracked or leaking exhaust manifolds can reduce engine performance and create harmful fumes.
mufflers.factthree: Regularly inspect your exhaust manifold for signs of damage, such as cracks or rust, to ensure proper engine function.

mufflers.name: Catalytic Converters
mufflers.factone: The catalytic converter reduces harmful emissions from your car's exhaust system.
mufflers.facttwo: A failing catalytic converter can trigger your check engine light and reduce your car's performance.
mufflers.factthree: Regular engine maintenance and using the correct fuel can help prolong the life of your catalytic converter.

other.name: TPMS Diagnostics
other.factone: The TPMS (Tire Pressure Monitoring System) alerts you when your tire pressure is low, helping prevent accidents and improve fuel efficiency.
other.facttwo: If your TPMS warning light is on, it's important to have your tire pressure checked and the system diagnosed for any faults.
other.factthree: Regularly checking your tire pressure and ensuring your TPMS sensors are functioning correctly can contribute to a safer and more efficient driving experience.

other.name: Shocks and Struts
other.factone: Shocks and struts are essential components of your suspension system, helping control your car's movement and absorb impacts.
other.facttwo: Worn shocks or struts can affect your car's handling, braking, and ride comfort. If you experience excessive bouncing or swaying, have them inspected.
other.factthree: Replacing worn shocks and struts can improve your car's safety and provide a smoother, more controlled ride.

other.name: AC Repair and Refill
other.factone: A properly functioning AC system keeps you cool and comfortable, especially during hot weather.
other.facttwo: If your AC isn't blowing cold air or is making strange noises, it might need a refrigerant refill or repair.
other.factthree: Regular AC maintenance, including inspections and recharges, can help prevent costly repairs and ensure optimal performance.
